canonical_explanation.text: Sexual reproduction in flowering plants (angiosperms) involves the flower as the reproductive organ. A typical flower has four whorls: calyx (sepals), corolla (petals), androecium (stamens - male), and gynoecium (pistil - female). Microsporogenesis occurs in the anther where microspore mother cells undergo meiosis to form microspore tetrads, which develop into pollen grains (male gametophytes). Each mature pollen grain has a two-celled structure with a generative cell and a vegetative (tube) cell, enclosed by exine (sporopollenin) and intine. Megasporogenesis occurs in the ovule where the megaspore mother cell undergoes meiosis forming four megaspores, of which usually one functional megaspore develops into the embryo sac (female gametophyte) by three successive mitotic divisions, forming a 7-celled, 8-nucleate structure. Pollination is the transfer of pollen from anther to stigma, occurring as self-pollination (autogamy) or cross-pollination (allogamy/xenogamy). Outbreeding devices include self-incompatibility, dichogamy, herkogamy, and dioecy. After pollination, pollen germinates on the stigma, the pollen tube grows through the style, and double fertilisation occurs: one sperm fuses with the egg (forming the diploid zygote) and the other fuses with the two polar nuclei (forming the triploid primary endosperm nucleus). The zygote develops into the embryo, ovules into seeds, and the ovary into the fruit. Apomixis is seed formation without fertilisation, polyembryony involves multiple embryos in a seed, and parthenocarpy produces seedless fruits.
rules: Microsporogenesis: microspore mother cell (2n) undergoes meiosis to form a tetrad of microspores (n) in the anther
Pollen grain has two layers: exine (sporopollenin, resistant) and intine (cellulose and pectin)
Megasporogenesis: megaspore mother cell (2n) in the ovule undergoes meiosis to form four megaspores; usually one is functional
Mature embryo sac is 7-celled, 8-nucleate: 1 egg cell + 2 synergids + 3 antipodals + 1 central cell (2 polar nuclei)
Self-pollination (autogamy): pollen transfer within the same flower; cross-pollination (xenogamy): between flowers of different plants
Outbreeding devices: self-incompatibility, dichogamy, herkogamy, and dioecy prevent self-pollination
Double fertilisation: one sperm + egg = zygote (2n); one sperm + polar nuclei = primary endosperm nucleus (3n)
Embryo development: zygote divides to form proembryo and then mature embryo with radicle, plumule, and cotyledons
Ovule develops into seed; ovary wall develops into fruit wall (pericarp)
Apomixis: formation of seeds without fertilisation; polyembryony: multiple embryos in one seed
Parthenocarpy: fruit development without fertilisation, producing seedless fruits

questions.question_text: The male reproductive part of a flower is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The stamen is the male reproductive part of a flower, collectively forming the androecium. Each stamen consists of a filament (stalk) and an anther (where pollen grains are produced).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pistil (gynoecium) is the female reproductive part. Sepals (calyx) are protective outer parts. Petals (corolla) attract pollinators. The stamen is the male reproductive organ.

questions.question_text: Microsporogenesis is the process of formation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Microsporogenesis is the process by which microspore mother cells (pollen mother cells, 2n) in the anther undergo meiosis to form a tetrad of haploid microspores (n). These microspores later develop into pollen grains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Megaspore formation is called megasporogenesis. Pollen tube formation occurs during germination. Embryo sac development is called megagametogenesis. Microsporogenesis specifically refers to microspore production.

questions.question_text: The outermost resistant wall layer of a pollen grain made of sporopollenin is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The exine is the outermost wall layer of the pollen grain, composed of sporopollenin, one of the most resistant biological materials known. It can withstand high temperatures, strong acids, and enzymatic degradation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Intine is the inner wall layer made of cellulose and pectin. Tapetum is a nutritive layer in the anther. Tectum is a layer within the exine. The exine is the outer protective layer of sporopollenin.

questions.question_text: A mature pollen grain in most angiosperms at the time of shedding is:

options.text: Two-celled with a generative cell and a vegetative cell
Three-celled with two synergids and an egg cell

questions.explanation_correct: At the time of shedding, a mature pollen grain in most angiosperms is two-celled, containing a larger vegetative cell and a smaller generative cell. The generative cell later divides to form two male gametes (sperm cells).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Single-celled pollen is immature. The three-celled structure with synergids and egg describes the egg apparatus in the embryo sac. A four-celled tetrad is formed during microsporogenesis before individual pollen grain development.

questions.question_text: The tapetum in the anther plays a crucial role because it:

options.text: Protects the anther from mechanical damage
Provides nourishment to the developing pollen grains

questions.explanation_correct: The tapetum is the innermost layer of the anther wall that provides nourishment to the developing microspores and pollen grains. Tapetal cells are rich in nutrients, produce Ubisch bodies, and contribute to the formation of the pollen coat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mechanical protection is provided by the outer anther wall layers. Female gametes are produced in the ovule. Dehiscence is facilitated by the endothecium. The tapetum's primary role is nutritive support for pollen development.

questions.question_text: The functional megaspore in a typical angiosperm ovule develops into the embryo sac by:
questions.explanation_correct: The functional megaspore undergoes three successive mitotic divisions to produce 8 nuclei, which organise into the 7-celled, 8-nucleate embryo sac (female gametophyte). This is the Polygonum type of embryo sac development.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meiosis already occurred during megaspore formation. Two mitotic divisions would produce only 4 nuclei. Three meiotic divisions are not involved. Exactly three mitotic divisions produce the 8 nuclei of the mature embryo sac.

questions.question_text: The embryo sac of a typical angiosperm at maturity is:
questions.explanation_correct: A mature embryo sac is 7-celled and 8-nucleate. It contains: 3 cells at the micropylar end (1 egg cell + 2 synergids), 3 antipodal cells at the chalazal end, and 1 central cell containing 2 polar nuclei. Total: 7 cells, 8 nuclei.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Although there are 8 nuclei, the central cell has 2 polar nuclei in one cell, making it 7 cells total, not 8. It is not 7-nucleate or 6-celled. The 7-celled, 8-nucleate structure is the standard Polygonum type.

questions.question_text: In the embryo sac, the synergids are located at the:

options.text: Micropylar end, flanking the egg cell
Centre of the embryo sac, near polar nuclei
Outside the embryo sac in the integuments

questions.explanation_correct: The two synergids are located at the micropylar end of the embryo sac, flanking the egg cell. Together, the egg cell and two synergids form the egg apparatus. Synergids have a special thickening called the filiform apparatus that guides the pollen tube.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antipodal cells are at the chalazal end. Polar nuclei are in the central cell. Synergids are inside the embryo sac, not in the integuments. They are specifically positioned at the micropylar end.

questions.question_text: Sporopollenin, which forms the exine of pollen grains, is significant because it is:

options.text: Easily degraded by enzymes, allowing quick germination
One of the most resistant biological materials, resistant to high temperatures, acids, and alkalis
A carbohydrate that provides energy for pollen tube growth
A protein that helps in pollen-stigma recognition

questions.explanation_correct: Sporopollenin is one of the most resistant organic materials known. It can withstand high temperatures, strong acids, alkalis, and enzymatic degradation. This makes pollen grains extremely well-preserved in fossil records and resistant to harsh environments.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sporopollenin is highly resistant, not easily degraded. It is not a carbohydrate or protein. Its resistance, not degradability, is its key feature. Pollen-stigma recognition involves proteins on the pollen coat, not sporopollenin.

questions.question_text: Germ pores in pollen grains are regions where:

options.text: Both exine and intine are absent
Exine is absent and intine is exposed
Intine is absent and exine is exposed

questions.explanation_correct: Germ pores are prominent apertures in the pollen grain where the exine (sporopollenin layer) is absent, exposing the intine. During germination, the pollen tube emerges through these germ pores.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The intine is present at germ pores and protrudes during germination. Both layers are not absent. Sporopollenin is absent, not maximum, at these points. Germ pores are gaps in the exine where the intine is exposed.

questions.question_text: The parts of a pistil are:
questions.explanation_correct: The pistil (gynoecium) consists of three parts: stigma (receptive surface for pollen), style (elongated connecting portion), and ovary (basal swollen part containing ovules). The pistil is the female reproductive organ of a flower.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anther, filament, and connective are parts of the stamen (male organ). Sepal, petal, and stamen are different floral whorls. Thalamus, peduncle, and bract are parts of the flower stalk. The pistil has stigma, style, and ovary.

questions.question_text: In the anther, the microspore mother cell is:

options.text: Haploid and undergoes mitosis to form pollen grains
Diploid and undergoes meiosis to form a tetrad of microspores
Haploid and undergoes meiosis to form spores

questions.explanation_correct: The microspore mother cell (pollen mother cell) is diploid (2n). It undergoes meiosis (reductional division) to produce a tetrad of four haploid (n) microspores. Each microspore then develops into a pollen grain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mother cell is diploid, not haploid or triploid. It undergoes meiosis, not mitosis. Meiosis can only occur in diploid cells. The result is four haploid microspores arranged as a tetrad.

questions.question_text: The filiform apparatus in the embryo sac is found in:
questions.explanation_correct: The filiform apparatus is a specialised finger-like projection of the cell wall found in the synergids at the micropylar end of the embryo sac. It plays an important role in guiding the pollen tube into the embryo sac.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Antipodal cells are at the chalazal end without a filiform apparatus. The egg cell does not possess it. The central cell contains polar nuclei. The filiform apparatus is unique to synergids and guides pollen tube entry.

questions.question_text: Transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of the same flower is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Autogamy (self-pollination) is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther to the stigma of the same flower. It ensures pollination even when pollinators are absent, as seen in cleistogamous flowers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Xenogamy is cross-pollination between flowers of different plants. Geitonogamy is pollination between different flowers of the same plant. Allogamy is another term for cross-pollination. Autogamy is self-pollination within the same flower.

questions.question_text: Geitonogamy is functionally equivalent to cross-pollination but genetically similar to self-pollination because:

options.text: Pollen comes from a different plant
It involves transfer by external agents but between flowers of the same plant
It always produces genetically different offspring
It does not require any pollinating agent

questions.explanation_correct: Geitonogamy involves transfer of pollen between different flowers of the same plant, requiring a pollinating agent (functionally cross-pollination). However, since both flowers are on the same plant, it is genetically equivalent to self-pollination as no new genetic material is introduced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In geitonogamy, pollen comes from the same plant, not a different one. It does not produce genetically different offspring. It does require a pollinating agent. Its unique nature is the functional-genetic duality.

questions.question_text: Cleistogamous flowers ensure self-pollination because they:

options.text: Never open, so pollen is transferred within the closed flower

questions.explanation_correct: Cleistogamous flowers (e.g., in Commelina, Viola, Oxalis) never open, ensuring that self-pollination (autogamy) occurs within the closed flower. This guarantees seed production even in the absence of pollinators.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cleistogamous flowers remain closed, unlike chasmogamous flowers that open. They produce both male and female parts. They do not rely on wind or insect pollination. Their closed nature ensures autogamy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an outbreeding device in flowering plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Self-incompatibility (SI) is an outbreeding device where the pistil rejects pollen from the same plant, preventing self-pollination and promoting cross-pollination. It is a genetic mechanism controlled by S-genes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cleistogamy promotes self-pollination, not outbreeding. Homogamy (simultaneous maturation of anthers and stigma) favours self-pollination. Autogamy is self-pollination. Self-incompatibility is a true outbreeding device.

questions.question_text: Wind-pollinated flowers typically have:

options.text: Feathery stigma and light, smooth pollen grains

questions.explanation_correct: Wind-pollinated (anemophilous) flowers have feathery or brush-like stigmas to catch airborne pollen, and they produce light, smooth, non-sticky pollen grains in large quantities. Examples include grasses, maize, and wheat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Brightly coloured petals, nectar, and fragrance are features of insect-pollinated flowers. Large, sticky pollen is characteristic of entomophilous (insect-pollinated) flowers. Wind-pollinated flowers are typically inconspicuous.

questions.question_text: Dichogamy is an outbreeding device in which:

options.text: Male and female flowers are on different plants
Anthers and stigma mature at different times in the same flower
Pollen grains are incompatible with the stigma of the same flower

questions.explanation_correct: Dichogamy is a temporal separation where anthers and stigma of the same flower mature at different times. If anthers mature first, it is protandry (e.g., sunflower); if stigma matures first, it is protogyny (e.g., Mirabilis). This prevents self-pollination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Separate male and female plants describe dioecy. Pollen incompatibility is self-incompatibility. Flowers that never open show cleistogamy. Dichogamy specifically involves different maturation times of anthers and stigma.

questions.question_text: Which of the following plants is pollinated by water (hydrophily)?
questions.explanation_correct: Vallisneria is a classic example of water-pollinated (hydrophilous) plant. In Vallisneria, female flowers reach the water surface, and male flowers are released to float and pollinate them. Zostera and Ceratophyllum are other examples.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Maize is wind-pollinated (anemophily). Salvia is insect-pollinated (entomophily). Bombax is pollinated by birds or bats. Vallisneria is the classic example of water pollination (hydrophily).

questions.question_text: Pollen grains of insect-pollinated flowers are generally:

options.text: Light, dry, and produced in enormous quantities
Sticky, spiny, or with an oily coating to adhere to insect bodies

questions.explanation_correct: Pollen grains of insect-pollinated (entomophilous) flowers are typically sticky, spiny, or coated with a sticky substance (pollenkitt) to adhere to the bodies of visiting insects. This ensures efficient pollen transfer between flowers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Light, dry pollen in large quantities is characteristic of wind-pollinated flowers. Pollen with no markings would not adhere to insects. Water dispersal occurs in hydrophilous plants. Insect-pollinated pollen is designed to stick.

questions.question_text: Dioecy as a breeding device means:

options.text: Male and female flowers on the same plant
Male and female flowers on different plants
Flowers have both stamens and pistils
Anthers and stigma mature at the same time

questions.explanation_correct: Dioecy means male and female flowers are borne on separate plants, making self-pollination impossible and ensuring cross-pollination. Examples include papaya, date palm, and mulberry.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Male and female flowers on the same plant describes monoecy. Flowers with both parts are bisexual (hermaphrodite). Simultaneous maturation is homogamy. Dioecy separates sexes on different plants.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Xenogamy is considered the most genetically beneficial type of pollination.
Reason: It involves pollen transfer between flowers of two genetically different plants of the same species.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is NOT the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Xenogamy (cross-pollination between different plants) introduces new gene combinations, providing maximum genetic variation, which is beneficial for adaptation and evolution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Xenogamy is indeed the most genetically beneficial type, and this is because it involves pollen from a genetically different plant of the same species, introducing new allele combinations.

questions.question_text: Herkogamy is an outbreeding device that involves:

options.text: Chemical incompatibility between pollen and stigma
Physical barrier between anther and stigma in the same flower
Different maturation times of anthers and stigma

questions.explanation_correct: Herkogamy involves a physical or spatial barrier between the anther and stigma within the same flower, preventing self-pollination. For example, in some flowers, the style may be longer than the stamens, or a structural barrier separates them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chemical incompatibility is self-incompatibility. Different maturation times describe dichogamy. Unisexual flowers on different plants is dioecy. Herkogamy specifically involves a physical/spatial separation.

questions.question_text: Double fertilisation in angiosperms involves:

options.text: Fusion of two eggs with two sperms
One sperm fusing with the egg and the other sperm fusing with the two polar nuclei
Fusion of two pollen grains with one egg
Fusion of the egg with a synergid

questions.explanation_correct: Double fertilisation, unique to angiosperms, involves two fusion events: one sperm fuses with the egg cell to form the diploid zygote (syngamy), and the other sperm fuses with the two polar nuclei to form the triploid primary endosperm nucleus (triple fusion).
questions.explanation_incorrect: There is only one egg cell. Two pollen grains are not involved. Synergids do not fuse with the egg. Double fertilisation specifically involves two sperms: one fertilising the egg and the other the central cell.

questions.question_text: The primary endosperm nucleus (PEN) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The primary endosperm nucleus (PEN) is triploid (3n) because it is formed by the fusion of one haploid (n) sperm nucleus with two haploid (n) polar nuclei in the central cell. This triple fusion (n + n + n = 3n) produces the triploid PEN.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Haploid describes gametes. Diploid describes the zygote. Tetraploid is not the standard ploidy. The PEN is specifically triploid because it results from the fusion of three haploid nuclei.

questions.question_text: After double fertilisation, the ovule develops into:
questions.explanation_correct: After double fertilisation, the ovule develops into the seed. Within the seed, the zygote develops into the embryo, and the primary endosperm nucleus develops into the endosperm. The integuments of the ovule become the seed coat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovary (not ovule) develops into the fruit. Pericarp develops from the ovary wall. Endosperm is only one component of the seed. The ovule as a whole transforms into the seed.

questions.question_text: The endosperm in angiosperms is:

options.text: Triploid tissue that provides nutrition to the developing embryo

questions.explanation_correct: The endosperm in angiosperms is a triploid (3n) tissue that develops from the primary endosperm nucleus (PEN). It serves as the nutritive tissue for the developing embryo, storing starch, proteins, and fats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Endosperm is formed after fertilisation (double fertilisation). It is triploid, not diploid. It is not part of the seed coat (which develops from integuments). The endosperm provides nutrition to the embryo.

questions.question_text: The entry of the pollen tube into the ovule through the micropyle is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Porogamy is the entry of the pollen tube into the ovule through the micropyle, which is the most common mode of pollen tube entry in angiosperms. This is the typical route for the pollen tube to reach the embryo sac.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chalazogamy is entry through the chalazal end. Mesogamy is entry through the integuments. Syngamy is the fusion of gametes. Porogamy specifically refers to entry through the micropyle.

questions.question_text: After fertilisation, the ovary wall develops into the:
questions.explanation_correct: After fertilisation, the ovary wall develops into the pericarp (fruit wall). The ovary as a whole develops into the fruit. The pericarp may be fleshy (as in mango) or dry (as in mustard).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The seed coat develops from the integuments of the ovule. Endosperm develops from the primary endosperm nucleus. The embryo develops from the zygote. The pericarp specifically comes from the ovary wall.

questions.question_text: In a dicot embryo, the two cotyledons are attached to the:

options.text: Embryonal axis at the cotyledonary node

questions.explanation_correct: In a dicot embryo, the two cotyledons are attached to the embryonal axis at the cotyledonary node. The embryonal axis has the radicle at one end (which develops into the root) and the plumule at the other end (which develops into the shoot).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cotyledons are not directly attached to the radicle or plumule but to the embryonal axis. They are not directly attached to the endosperm. The cotyledonary node on the embryonal axis is the point of attachment.

questions.question_text: In monocot seeds like maize, the endosperm is NOT consumed during seed development. Instead, the embryo is nourished during germination through a specialised structure called:
questions.explanation_correct: In monocot seeds like maize, the scutellum is the single cotyledon that acts as a specialised absorptive structure. It is located between the embryo and the endosperm and helps in absorbing nutrients from the endosperm during germination.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coleoptile is the protective sheath around the plumule (shoot). Coleorhiza is the sheath around the radicle (root). The aleurone layer produces enzymes but is not the absorptive structure. The scutellum is the specialised cotyledon.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly represents the fate of floral parts after fertilisation?

options.text: Ovary -> Fruit; Ovule -> Seed; Integuments -> Seed coat
Ovule -> Fruit; Ovary wall -> Seed coat

questions.explanation_correct: After fertilisation: the ovary develops into the fruit, the ovule develops into the seed, and the integuments of the ovule develop into the seed coat (testa and tegmen). The zygote becomes the embryo and the PEN becomes the endosperm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ovary does not become the seed; it becomes the fruit. The ovule does not become the fruit; it becomes the seed. The zygote becomes the embryo, not endosperm. Option B correctly maps each structure.

questions.question_text: True fruit develops from the:
questions.explanation_correct: A true fruit develops from the ovary of the flower after fertilisation. Examples include mango, tomato, and grapes. If other floral parts (like thalamus) also contribute to fruit formation, it is called a false fruit (e.g., apple, strawberry).
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the thalamus contributes, it is a false fruit (pseudocarp). Calyx and petals do not form the main body of a true fruit. A true fruit develops exclusively from the ovary.

questions.question_text: In albuminous seeds, the endosperm:

options.text: Is completely consumed during embryo development
Persists in the mature seed and provides nutrition during germination

questions.explanation_correct: In albuminous (endospermic) seeds, the endosperm persists in the mature seed and is not completely consumed during embryo development. It provides nutrition during seed germination. Examples include castor, maize, wheat, and coconut.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Complete consumption of endosperm occurs in exalbuminous seeds (like peas, beans). Endosperm is present initially in all angiosperm seeds. It does not transform into the seed coat. Albuminous seeds retain their endosperm.

questions.question_text: The phenomenon in which the pollen tube enters the ovule through the chalazal end is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Chalazogamy is the entry of the pollen tube into the ovule through the chalazal end (opposite to the micropyle). This is seen in Casuarina. It was first discovered by Treub.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Porogamy is entry through the micropyle (most common). Mesogamy is entry through the integuments. Cleistogamy refers to closed flowers. Chalazogamy specifically involves entry through the chalazal end.

questions.question_text: Exalbuminous seeds differ from albuminous seeds in that they:

options.text: Have endosperm consumed during development, with food stored in cotyledons

questions.explanation_correct: In exalbuminous (non-endospermic) seeds, the endosperm is completely consumed during embryo development. The food reserves are instead stored in the fleshy cotyledons. Examples include pea, groundnut, and bean.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All angiosperm seeds initially develop endosperm; in exalbuminous seeds it is consumed. The embryo is always diploid, not triploid. Seed coat is present in all seeds. The key difference is endosperm consumption and cotyledon storage.

questions.question_text: Apomixis refers to:

options.text: Seed production through normal sexual reproduction

questions.explanation_correct: Apomixis is a form of asexual reproduction in plants where seeds are produced without fertilisation. The embryo develops from the diploid cells of the ovule (e.g., nucellus or integuments) without meiosis or gamete fusion. Examples include some grasses and Asteraceae.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Normal sexual reproduction involves fertilisation. Fruit production without pollination is parthenocarpy. Pollen formation without meiosis is not apomixis. Apomixis specifically refers to seed formation without fertilisation.

questions.question_text: Polyembryony is the occurrence of:

options.text: Multiple embryos in a single seed
Multiple pollen tubes entering one ovule

questions.explanation_correct: Polyembryony is the occurrence of more than one embryo in a single seed. It can occur through cleavage of the zygotic embryo or from the development of cells of the nucellus or integuments. Citrus fruits commonly show polyembryony.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Multiple seeds in one fruit is a normal occurrence. Multiple fruits from one flower is not polyembryony. Multiple pollen tubes can enter but that is polyspermy. Polyembryony specifically means multiple embryos in one seed.

questions.question_text: Parthenocarpy is the development of:
questions.explanation_correct: Parthenocarpy is the development of fruit without fertilisation, resulting in seedless fruits. Examples include seedless grapes, bananas, and watermelons. It can occur naturally or be induced by growth hormones like auxins and gibberellins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seed production without fertilisation is apomixis. Embryo from diploid cells is a type of apomixis. Endosperm without triple fusion is not parthenocarpy. Parthenocarpy produces seedless fruits.

questions.question_text: Apomixis is commercially significant in agriculture because:

options.text: It produces seedless fruits for the market
It can be used to maintain hybrid vigour in crop plants across generations
It increases genetic variation in crops
It eliminates the need for irrigation

questions.explanation_correct: Apomixis is commercially significant because seeds produced apomictically are clones of the mother plant. This means hybrid vigour (heterosis) can be maintained across generations without the segregation that occurs in sexually produced seeds, saving the cost of producing hybrid seeds each year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Seedless fruit production is parthenocarpy, not apomixis. Apomixis decreases genetic variation as offspring are clones. It has no relation to irrigation needs. Its key value is maintaining hybrid vigour.

questions.question_text: In citrus fruits, extra embryos arise from:
questions.explanation_correct: In citrus, polyembryony occurs when cells of the nucellus (diploid tissue surrounding the embryo sac) start dividing and develop into additional embryos alongside the zygotic embryo. These nucellar embryos are genetically identical to the parent plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While zygotic cleavage can cause polyembryony, in citrus it is specifically the nucellar cells that form extra embryos. Synergid and antipodal cells do not typically form additional embryos. Nucellar polyembryony is characteristic of citrus.

questions.question_text: Seedless banana is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Seedless banana is a classic example of natural parthenocarpy, where the fruit develops without fertilisation and hence contains no seeds. Banana plants are propagated vegetatively through suckers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Apomixis produces seeds without fertilisation. Polyembryony involves multiple embryos in a seed. Double fertilisation is a normal sexual process. Parthenocarpy specifically produces seedless fruits.

questions.question_text: Which of the following hormones can be used to induce parthenocarpy artificially?
questions.explanation_correct: Gibberellins can be applied to unpollinated pistils to induce parthenocarpic fruit development. Auxins can also be used. This is commercially important for producing seedless fruits like grapes and tomatoes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Abscisic acid promotes dormancy and inhibits growth. Ethylene promotes fruit ripening and senescence. Cytokinins promote cell division but are not typically used for parthenocarpy. Gibberellins are the standard choice.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Apomixis and parthenocarpy are different phenomena.
Reason: Apomixis produces seeds without fertilisation while parthenocarpy produces fruits without fertilisation.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is NOT the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Apomixis produces seeds without fertilisation (embryo develops from diploid cells), while parthenocarpy produces seedless fruits without fertilisation. These are distinct phenomena.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are factually correct, and the reason accurately explains why they are different phenomena. Apomixis yields seeds with embryos, while parthenocarpy yields seedless fruits.

questions.question_text: In apomictic species, the embryo may develop from a diploid cell of the nucellus without undergoing:
questions.explanation_correct: In adventive embryony (a type of apomixis), the embryo develops from diploid nucellar cells without meiosis (no gamete formation) and without fertilisation. The resulting embryo is genetically identical to the parent plant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitosis is required for cell division and embryo growth. Cell differentiation is needed for embryo development. DNA replication occurs during cell division. The key omissions in apomixis are meiosis and fertilisation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of polyembryony?
questions.explanation_correct: Orange (Citrus) is a classic example of polyembryony where multiple embryos develop in a single seed. Extra embryos arise from the nucellar cells of the ovule. Other examples include mango and lemon.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wheat, rice, and mustard typically have a single embryo per seed. Orange and other citrus fruits are well-known examples of polyembryony due to the development of nucellar embryos.

questions.question_text: A plant breeder wants to produce seedless watermelons for commercial sale. Which technique is most appropriate?

options.text: Induction of parthenocarpy using plant growth regulators

questions.explanation_correct: To produce seedless fruits, the breeder should induce parthenocarpy using plant growth regulators like gibberellins or auxins. This causes fruit development without fertilisation, resulting in seedless watermelons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cross-pollination would produce seeds. Apomixis produces seeds (without fertilisation). Self-pollination also produces seeds. Only parthenocarpy produces seedless fruits.

questions.question_text: The nucellar embryos formed during polyembryony in citrus are:

options.text: Genetically different from the mother plant due to meiosis
Genetically identical to the mother plant as they arise from diploid somatic cells
Haploid and require fertilisation to develop further

questions.explanation_correct: Nucellar embryos are genetically identical to the mother plant because they develop from diploid somatic cells of the nucellus through mitotic divisions without meiosis or fertilisation. They are essentially clones of the parent.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No meiosis is involved, so they are not genetically different. They are diploid (not haploid) and do not require fertilisation. They are not triploid. Nucellar embryos are diploid clones of the mother plant.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about double fertilisation is INCORRECT?

options.text: It involves the fusion of two sperms with different cells of the embryo sac
It results in the formation of a diploid zygote and a triploid PEN
It occurs in all gymnosperms and angiosperms

questions.explanation_correct: It is incorrect to say that double fertilisation occurs in gymnosperms. Double fertilisation is unique to angiosperms (flowering plants). Gymnosperms have single fertilisation only. Options A, B, and C are all correct statements about double fertilisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is correct as double fertilisation is unique to angiosperms. Option B is correct as one sperm fuses with the egg and the other with polar nuclei. Option C is correct about the ploidy. Only option D is incorrect.
